items.title: What caused Jeju Air plane crash in South Korea? | DW News
items.author: DW News
items.content:
World leaders have been sending condolences to South Korea, after the country's deadliest aviation disaster on home soil. 179 passengers and crew aboard the Jeju Air flight were killed when the Boeing 737-800 skidded off the runway at Muan International Airport and burst into flames. Only two crew members survived. Investigators have recovered both flight recorders as they try to piece together what happened.

items.title: Worst airline disaster in South Korean history | DW News
items.author: DW News
items.content:
179 passengers and crew aboard the Jeju Air flight were killed when the Boeing 737-800 skidded off the runway at Muan International Airport and burst into flames. Two crew members rescued from the tail section were the only survivors. Both in hospital with non-life-threatening injuries. The South Korean government has declared a week of mourning for the victims.

items.title: Jeju Air jet crash: Death toll rises to at least 151 people in South Korea | DW News
items.author: DW News
items.content:
A passenger jet has crashed upon landing in South Korea, killing at least 151 people. The Jeju Air flight from Bangkok skidded off the runway at Muan International Airport, crashed into a barrier and burst into flames. 181 people were on board the flight. Only two people have been rescued from the tail section of the Boeing 737-800. Officials say there's little chance of finding other survivors, which would make it South Korea's worst aviation disaster. 

Chapter Breakdown
0:00 Jeju Air passenger jet crashes in South Korea, only two survivors confirmed
1:42 Jen Moon, Journalist at Muan International Airport, on what authorities know so far
4:24 Richard Levy, Aviation expert, on possible causes of crash

items.title: South Korea: Jeju Air plane skidded off runway, killing at least 47 people | DW News
items.author: DW News
items.content:
A plane crashed at Muan International Airport in South Korea, killing at least 47 people, according to South Korean authorities. The Jeju Air flight with 181 people skidded off the runway and slammed into a wall before catching fire. At least two people have been rescued.  

The flight was flying back from Bangkok in Thailand, and the incident took place while it was landing. According to the emergency office and local media, the landing gear malfunctioned, causing the plane to run off the runway, hit a fence, and catch fire. 

For more news go to: http://www.dw.com/en/

items.title: Syria authorities launch operation in Assad stronghold - Are loyalists a threat? | DW News
items.author: DW News
items.content:
Syria's new administration is stepping up its campaign to track down members of the ousted regime of Bashar al-Assad. 

Over the weekend, security forces deployed to the Latakia region to flush out remnants of Assad militias and confiscate weapons and ammunition. Syria's new rulers have been working to assert their authority.

Assad has since fled to Moscow to escape the takeover.

items.title: Israel raids last major hospital in northern Gaza, detains director | DW News
items.author: DW News
items.content:
Israel's military says its raid on the Kamal Adwan hospital in northern Gaza is over. The operation allegedly targeted a Hamas command center hidden in the compound. Israel detained the hospital director and 240 others as suspected Hamas militants

items.title: India mourns former Indian Prime Minister Manmohan Singh | DW News
items.author: DW News
items.content:
The state funeral for former Indian Prime Minister Manmohan Singh began on Saturday as mourners gathered in the capital bid farewell to the leader who oversaw the country's economic liberalization. The 92-year-old Singh, who served as prime minister from 2004 to 2014, passed away on Thursday.

00:00 State funeral for former Indian Prime Minister Manmohan Singh
01:45 Manoj Joshi, Distinguished Fellow, Observer Research Foundation

items.title: Kremlin: Air defense active during plane approach | DW News
items.author: DW News
items.content:
Russian President Vladimir Putin has apologized for what he called the "tragic incident" in Russian airspace leading to the downing of an Azerbaijani passenger plane. Putin told his Azerbaijani counterpart that Russian air defenses were 'active' before the plane crashed in Kazakhstan, killing 38 people. He stopped short of admitting responsibility.
